About Approach Recruitment Prototype Pilot Learnings Future Contact

DELTALUMIN 1.0

One of Delta Institute’s strategic objectives is to “disrupt the energy status quo.” We work to meet this objective by helping buildings become more efficient, finding creative strategies to increase renewable energy generation, and, in this case, by working directly with energy users to find out how they interact with their electricity and what kinds of things motivate them to make changes in their homes.

Delta has a history of working directly with homeowners on energy conservation. For years, we implemented a home weatherization program to help homeowners better understand where energy was escaping through the walls of their homes, then guided them toward smart home investments to address the problem. For DeltaLumin, we wanted to try something a bit different. Instead of designing a program, then heading out into the community to implement our idea, we decided to flip the script. We wanted to head out into the community first, allowing us to better understand the needs of the people we were serving. We wanted to ask questions, observe actions, and have lots of conversations before building anything out.

As these ideas began to solidify, the Illinois Science & Energy Innovation Foundation (ISEIF) announced a round of funding that seemed to match our objectives. We knew we would need a partner to handle much of the design and research work (Delta is not a product development firm) and approach renowned design firm IDEO, who were excited to help us design some great product concepts. We also needed to expand our reach deep into what ISEIF considers “hard to reach” communities, including seniors and low-income individuals. To do so, we reached out to one of our long-time partners, Faith in Place, who would lead up community outreach and recruitment.


The rest of this site will walk through our process, findings, technical documentation, and next steps for DeltaLumin year 2. We hope that, by telling our story in the open, others can learn from our work and make an impact in their communities.

The DeltaLumin Approach

Research Design

The primary research question was whether the illumination of energy use data will lead low-income energy consumers to engage with their energy use beyond the level of engagement that occurs with the use of traditional monthly bills? Where illumination of energy use involves translating household energy use into personalized information about participants’ energy habits and patterns. Engagement includes demonstrating energy use reduction through action, stating an intention to reduce energy use, and/or indicating that an informed decision was made to not reduce energy use. Low-income energy consumers include individuals with a household income at or below 50% AMI (< 150% FPL) who are not currently receiving energy subsidies (e.g. CEDA, LIHEAP).

Energy use was illuminated using four different features include:

    1. Spending Forecast, which tested if energy spending updates at a shorter interval (daily rather than monthly) leads to increased levels of engagement over those receiving traditional monthly bills
    2. Appliance Spending Diagnosis, which tested if appliance-level energy consumption information is a more accessible illumination of energy use leading to increased levels of engagement over those receiving traditional monthly bills
    3. Energy Savings Goal, which tested if facilitating energy savings goals among participants leads to increased levels of engagement over those receiving traditional monthly bills
    4. Program Match, which tested if a curated list of existing utility programs based on actual household energy use data will lead to increased levels of engagement over those receiving traditional monthly bills

Each feature was delivered to participants in one or more of the following channels of communication per their stated preference:

    1. Mail (push/analog)
    2. Email (push/digital)
    3. Website (fetch/digital)

Workshop Series

Throughout the DeltaLumin Pilot Program there were five in-person events including two kick-off events and three pilot participant workshops. The purpose of these events was to gain insight into the participants’ reactions to the forms in which DeltaLumin communicates their energy use data. This was accomplished through open-ended discussion, written surveys, and facilitated activities.

Pilot Kick-Off Event: Introduction to the Program

Pilot participants working through the energy scale activity

Objective: To develop a baseline for both participants’ personal energy use and their understanding of energy.

Exercise: In anticipation of the first Energy Update, which would include an Appliance Spending Diagnosis outlining estimated energy use per appliance, the Kick-Off activity aimed to better understand how participants currently think about the energy consumption of individual appliances.

Results: Donec elementum tellus vitae diam facilisis, in eleifend mi maximus. Fusce erat tortor, pharetra ac cursus at, volutpat eu sem.
